content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Jogo simplesmente sensacional! O que posso dizer de um jogo como este, onde eu posso criar o meu próprio Super-Herói ou me inspirar nos que eu assistia e lia quando criança? Poxa, encontrei esse jogo tarde de mais eu acho, gostaria de ter o conhecido mais cedo, porque cara, que joguinho pra viciar. Os gráficos para um MMO são lindos, e os poderes que se pode ter também. As quests são em geral fáceis, mas as dungeons são muito ♥♥♥♥! Proporcionando ao jogador uma dificuldade razoável, onde várias vezes você vai morrer, até você achar o ponto fraco do inimigo e bater lá. O jogo tem um sistema de cash e premium member, ou Legendary, mas não muda em nada o gameplay, só da ao jogador vantagens de ter TODAS as DLCs do jogo de graça e a opção de criar uma Liga, e o preço do membro mensal não chega a ser tão caro, R$23,99, sendo que nos EUA são U$14,99, ou seja, estamos saindo com lucro, pois a mensalidade seria quase R$60,00. Mas enfim, não estou dizendo para você pagar mensalmente, você pode simplesmente comprar as DLCs e viver sua vida.   A busca pelo level 30 é complicada, demora bastante para você upar, tendo que fazer duas ou até mesmo 3 missões para upar metade do level, mas é assim mesmo, se você quer facilidade vai jogar Minecraft.    Enfim pessoal, jogo 100% recomendado, se você gosta do universo DC, você vai amar esse jogo, os gráficos são lindos, a jogabilidade quase que perfeita, a história é boa, e a dublagem em inglês sensacional.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												For those out of the loop, this probably represents the last of the big old-style MMOs. Even though it was only released in 2011, there’s something about it that feels more tired than Bruce Wayne’s put upon butler. Indeed, there’s a grind to almost every mission, the graphics don’t exactly sparkle (even on new hardware), and how you choose to fight seems to have very little bearing on the outcome of battle. Speedy level progression and focus on all combat, all the time might prove tedious if you're someone who enjoys exploring new worlds for the thrill of mystery and discovery. The largely instanced, repeatable endgame content is fun, but it's not inviting enough to make it worth paying a monthly fee for it. But even if it doesn't provide enough new content to sustain you beyond a couple of weeks, DC Universe Online is generally entertaining, and comic book fans will be happy that the license was handled with care.Perhaps the best gameplay feature of DCUO is the design of its default UI layout and keybinds. Instead of the standard MMOG mechanic of "tab-target, auto-attack, fire-all-your-cooldowns-and-wait-for-refresh" that leaves you a slave to whack-a-mole style hotbuttons and timers, DCUO maps the entirety of your primary weapon set to a single button. Through a series of "clicks" and "holds," your avatar will execute different combinations of superpowered techniques that are the bread and butter of your life as a hero or villain. The additional powers you can use are yours to command at YOUR discretion, not the whim of a global cooldown, and you may find yourself going as long as an hour or two without needing to activate a single one. This combination of simplicity and freedom allow you to do something that has become less common in MMOGs - you can actually watch the action unfold instead of always having your eyes fixed to your hotbars. This also has allowed the DCUO devs to include clever boss fight mechanics that include a reliance on environmental awareness, since it's easier to see what's going on around you.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Experience: Played this in closed beta, and open beta, pre-order, pay to play for a month and got tired of poor world pvp mechanics and quit. It went free to play and I tried it out again much later and it was fun for kicking around in PvE and I leveled a few more toons to the cap level of 30. I have 3 level 30 Villains and 3 level 30 Heroes.PvE: The grind to get into raiding is more than I have ever seen in an MMO and I have played a lot of them. Game mechanics for raids are very poor. You expect to be leveling a very active controller character and end up standing around with your thumb up your butt just handing out energy to the tanks and healer. The one big raiding guild that I had joined was full of "lifers" (people who had purchased a lifetime subscription to the game) and they added their own drama to the game to spice it up... I was banned for being "a potential spy"... PvP: The PvP mechanics in the arenas are evolutionary, however severely unbalanced even more than other MMOs. Open World PvP is similar mechanics where there is a mirror world where everyone can PvP no matter your level. Level 30s often squish low level players for kicks.Social: The game keeps coming out with new paid expansions, however the population continues to dwindle. I still have the game installed because I like the PvE fighting mechanics. It's fun to watch some of the combos and devastation in your wake. Hardly anyone reads the chat, and its near imposable to get into an active guild because most of them are dead. Opinion: It's fun to tool around with a buddy, just don't expect to be able to play with your friends right away. The introduction to the game is roughly 15-30 mins long depending on your experience with the game. I still keep it installed just to pop in from time to time and beat down some mobs.

												I love this game. Me and my Father in-law play it almost every night together. It's pretty cheap to get a membership ($15 a  month but cheaper if you get for 3/6/12 months.) at first I chose to stick with 1 month at a time to see if i would like it and im hooked! I now have a 3-month reacurring membership. I have over 650 hours played among 2 characters, and thats just from February. My Father in-law has over 2000 on steam and that doesn't count before it was on steam. Yes there are a lot of DLC's but that makes it fun, there is so much content to complete. This game could be boring if you play it as a solo player. I.e not in a league or not with friends. I am in an active league with +100 members and there's always someone to talk to and make friends. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Don't let my time on record fool you, I have sunk thousands of hours and dollars into this game since it launched on PS3. At one time I considered DCUO my favorite game of all time and I met some really cool people through it. The game had unlimited potential with an original combat system and the DC comics backing that had me pumped to be apart of it from the start and excited for the future. Unfortunately, over the last few years the devs have consistently made changes that have hurt the game and player base. It's obvious to me that the game is now just an ultimate cash grab for every single thing they implement. Bugs take years to get fixed unless they take money out of their pockets. New added powers come out completely overpowered so everyone pays to switch to them and then a month or so later get nerfed into the ground so you need to switch in order to stay competitive. There is zero benefit to being a player who puts a lot of money into the game. You can now pay to own powers at $5 each, but why is it that if I "own" the powerset on the game that I still have to pay $10 to change to the power on my hero/villain? The last straw for me was them implementing "stat flattening" or "stat clamping" whatever you/ they want to call it. I played this game to make my character stronger and feel like a growing superhero among other superheroes, not to get to a certain level and then get weaker for older content! I would love for the game to start making better steps and entice me to come back, but I fear things are just going to get worse because of the greed of the developers.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												OverviewTLDR: If you don't plan to invest more than 8 hours a day for a few months into this game, don't bother getting the DLC or any other product that requires money. It's a very small great game wrapped in a much larger awful game. It is not casual friendly after level 30.After having played this game an absurd amount of time for a casual gamer (which I measure by comparing it to the amount of time I spend playing any other game, which is about 4-6 hours a day, depending on how entertaining it is), I found myself enjoying it quite a bit. I got a few characters to level 30 and started to play some of the beginning endgame content to come to a startling realization.For the "casual" gamer, DCUO is a huge waste of time. What do I mean by "casual" gamer? I mean a person who enjoys a few hours of game play a day in between other responsibilities and games you enjoy. This game has a lot of fun and attractive elements. It aged well for a game that has been around since 2011. It is well set into the DC universe (no pun intended) and has all of the characters you've come to enjoy. The character creation and powers are entertaining and give you many ways to configure your appearance and show off some creativity. Combat will draw you in and the storylines are very fun, even after multiple playthroughs. The voice acting for the heroes and villains are also extremely well performed and makes you feel like a part of their world. Getting to level 30 is very enjoyable. It was for these reasons that I bought the DLC. I wanted more of this. It turns out that this was the end of all the fun was going to have with this game.Once you hit level 30 the "real" game begins. And by real, I mean the un-fun grinding of worthless items to afford 1/10th of one percent of the actual gear you will need to actually make mission progress. Most MMO games are like this... it gets to a point where it stops becoming a roleplaying superhero game and starts being "Number Watcher: The Game." One finds themselves needing to raise one's stats to an arbitrary level before one may progress further. This becomes the norm, completely independent of any kind of roleplaying element.This is not helped at all by the other major sin of this game which is that the descriptions for items you buy/receive are useless and misleading. I have many examples of misleading object listings, but here are a few. When trying to trade with other players, it will tell you that a subscription is necessary to enable trading of items and money. This is misleading, since it implies you may NOT trade items and money without a subscription when, in fact, you can trade items. Yes, you need a subscription to trade in-game cash, but the items, provided they are not locked to an account, may be traded as you like.Another example is that it is not particularly clear what marketplace items can be traded to other players. One may not trade armories (a new addition to the game) that have been purchased nor can one trade "station cash" to other players. You also cannot buy DLC with station cash. Sony removed this ability after losing a significant amount of money, meaning you're going to have to buy it direct from steam or some other process. The marketplace locations, however, do not tell you this. They are marked with "buy now" buttons which take you to the website where you can purchase them directly. Why are the DLC in the shop at all if you can't buy them with station cash? This has led a number of people to purchase station cash only to be disappointed in finding that they had made an expensive mistake. Further examples? The "end-game" armor I mentioned earlier is not well marked. Certain armors are meant to improve PvE rating and other improve PvP ratings. While this is an important distinction, neither armor is marked as exclusively useful for one or the other. You have to find this out on your own or consult the DCUO wiki.Some of the end-game missions that they give you off the bat are meant for multiple people. It is true that Calculator tells you this, but the missions themselves are not clearly marked like the on-duty counterparts. Or you can consult the DCUO Wiki. You can also make items and objects that can be used in combat using "exobite data." This is a significant portion of the armor crafting process. How do you accomplish this? They don't tell you it. You need to ask or consult the wiki.For most problems, one has to frequently indulge the DCUO wiki for information on what terms or requirements are needed and they are not always clear. The forums are full of people asking (if not begging) for clarification on what needs doing or what certain descriptions mean. The Stats and power descriptions are also very poorly done and do not fully explain what the powers do in a clear and understandable way. Perhaps one of the biggest problems with unclear descriptions is the way that the DLC advertise new missions and the like for your character. What they do NOT tell you is that in order to actually use most of the PvE content, you need to have a high "combat rating". What is the "combat rating" you ask? The wiki is the place to go for the answers, but even then, I found myself asking people "How do I start the War of the Light DLC?" only to be told I need a combat rating of 84 or, roughly, tier 4 armor.  The more formidable your armor, the higher your rating.To receive tiered armor, you must play missions to achieved "Marks of valor" or "marks of triumph" or whatever other marks are required to purchase the desired armor. The better the armor, the higher your combat rating. It requires a combat rating of 84 to use the Tier 5 armor, so one assumes one needs a complete set of Tier 4 armor to achieve this goal. To accomplish this, it requires an endless amount of grinding missions within a given tier from the "on duty" menu to farm the marks to get the armor to get the missions from the DLCIf you just beat the game and are now level 30? That's likely months away from the completion of the "end game." When I made this realization, all desire to continue playing left my body, along with any sense of fun and enjoyment. I'd have to make this game my job in order to see the DLC I just purchased anytime soon.  These requirements are not described anywhere on the DLC's purchase page. I would not have spent a single cent if there had been even one cautionary word relating to "combat ratings" needing to be obtained in order to use the majority of the features contained within the DLC. This game is not for the casual player. It is meant for someone with a lot of free time and money to spend and little else to do. Maybe after a year or so, a casual player might be able to make it to a high enough level to use the DLC, but those people will likely be weeded out by the dedicated grinders who make it their job to keep casuals out of major battle groups for the sake of improving the odds of success over teaching people who have not made this game their religion.There are MMOs that are friendlier to new and casual players. That said, play this game. Its free. Play it to level 30 and have fun. After that, drop it like a bad habit. If you're a hard core MMORPG player, then you'll probably like all the PVP stuff and the high level gear that you can lord over other players. I wouldn't know because I'm not one of those.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												How did this game survive when City of Heroes died out?I have played through the game three times now and completed the story as a Tech, Meta, and Magic character. But once you hit level 30 and complete the main story, there is nothing left to do except PVP, which unless you're shilling out the dollars (or whatever currency your country runs on), you're pretty much guaranteed to lose.The power selection is also EXTREMELY limited compared to other super hero games like City of Heroes, or Champions Online. Each power set is divided up into two types which as far as I can tell boil down to DPS vs Crowd Control.Their website hasn't been updated since War of the Light, so I'm going to tell you which power sets are available in the game as of the time of writing this. The Power Sets for those who aren't paying a subscription are Fire, Ice, Gadgets, Mental, Nature, and Sorcery.The powers sets for those who do pay a subscription includes the previons ones, as well as Light (green / yellow rings), Rage (red ring), Earth, Lightning, Quantum (time / space),  Blessed / Cursed (good and evil magic), and Munitions (lots of guns).They also plan to include additional paid for powers such as Water and Serums.Unfortunately these new power sets contribute nothing to the game's replay value. The story is the same regardless, and once again, there's nothing to do except PVP once you complete it.The game has also begun to die out. When I first starting playing the game, the streets were filled with heroes and villains. When I tried to do a PVP server, I could scarcely go on a mission without being dog piled by the enemy team. Now the game is mostly deserted on both PVP and PVE servers. I think I found maybe 2 or 3 enemies that were still hunting players on PVP servers, but that's it.The only travel powers that are any fun is Speed Force and Acrobatics. Flight and the hover discs are a joke, nobody seems to like them. Probably because at a certain level, you can get a jet booster with Acrobatics that allows you to get around just as easily as flight, and in a much faster method. That's right, FLIGHT is the slowest travel power in the game!The game also lacks a character diversity concept such as races. I get that the story is that you were a human that inherited super powers, but they could have at least included a racial template such as Thanagarian, Kryptonian, Martian, Atlantean, Cyborg, Robot, and so on. You can get skins for some of these races, and you can get similar powers, but these are purely cosmetic and don't affect your strengths and weaknesses at all.DC Universe Online is a super hero game that falls short when compared to many other games of its genre. It is not worth the money they want you to pump into it, and is already dying as it is. The game should be allowed to go out with whatever dignity it has left, rather than trying to resuscitate it.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Don't let my time on record fool you, I have sunk thousands of hours and dollars into this game since it launched on PS3. At one time I considered DCUO my favorite game of all time and I met some really cool people through it. The game had unlimited potential with an original combat system and the DC comics backing that had me pumped to be apart of it from the start and excited for the future. Unfortunately, over the last few years the devs have consistently made changes that have hurt the game and player base. It's obvious to me that the game is now just an ultimate cash grab for every single thing they implement. Bugs take years to get fixed unless they take money out of their pockets. New added powers come out completely overpowered so everyone pays to switch to them and then a month or so later get nerfed into the ground so you need to switch in order to stay competitive. There is zero benefit to being a player who puts a lot of money into the game. You can now pay to own powers at $5 each, but why is it that if I "own" the powerset on the game that I still have to pay $10 to change to the power on my hero/villain? The last straw for me was them implementing "stat flattening" or "stat clamping" whatever you/ they want to call it. I played this game to make my character stronger and feel like a growing superhero among other superheroes, not to get to a certain level and then get weaker for older content! I would love for the game to start making better steps and entice me to come back, but I fear things are just going to get worse because of the greed of the developers.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Time for a good, bad, and ugly review. (NON PVP player) Final verdict at the end. ****************  The Good things *********************Character generation – IMHO more MMO's should adopt this style of both character creation, and customization.  Your stats and abilities are almost totally independent of your characters appearance, and there are a LOT of appearance options to customize your hero.  I personally Cosplay my DC character as Starlord from the Guardians of the Galaxy movie, and it looks and feels awesome to play!Action/fighting/button mashing combat – If you are like me, you are sick of the action/hotbar style mmo mechanic.  This game has a more traditional action game approach to controls, and works BEST with a controller, but also well with a mouse and keyboard. If you like Games that give you button combos, active dodging and countering, you will like this.  Story – It is clearly a “theme park” mmo in every sense of the word.  IMHO it does this well, each story arc is mostly fun, and only a handful felt boring or like something I couldn't wait to finish.  Nothing too deep, nothing too shallow. Nice bite sized plots that you can finish in a few hours at a time. Great for casual gaming. Gotham – The city of Gotham is legit, and makes you feel like you are in the Batman animated series in many ways. Sound and graphics – for an MMO, these look great with everything maxed out.  The colors, the characters, and the environments (especially gotham) are full of eye candy.  Gameplay overall – The game play is very addictive as I mentioned before, even just flying/running/climbing around the cities is fun. The fighting action is great. But another great thing are the movement modes, I find acrobatics/grapplinghook to be the most fun to play, and flight to be the most useful. Free to play – This is kind of both a good and bad – the free to play model being used here is what I prefer to call – the Extended preview model.  The free elements are enough to level you to 30 and beyond, but you will be limited in a lot of ways, and won't get to experiment with all the possible power and weapon combos.  As free to play games go, if you enjoy the game you will be getting a LOT out of the game even if you never buy anything. ********************* The bad things ************************Grind - The level range is only 1-30, and when it finishes, the game devolves into repeating content for marks which you use to buy gear that raises your level (similar to destiny's light level).  This is fun for a little while, but once you see how long it takes to grind for marks, and how much content you have to repeat to do it... you will likely quit, most people I know get their full Tier 1, then either quit, or make a new toon experience another storyline up to thirty, then quit. Lots of empty space – I can't tell you how often I'm traveling around, especially in Metropolis, and feel like the city is empty and unfinished.  Huge sections of the map have almost no reason for going there, except exploring for collectible elements.  No random enemies to fight, no quests... I'd say only about 1/3 of the map for each city has actual content in it, the rest is just travel and exploration fodder. The hideout system – This is boring to me, it's got a lot going for it I suppose if you like these things, but I just can't get into the layouts or designs.  However, unlike most other MMO's where a home is just a fun vanity collectible box, you NEED a hideout or else you won't get certain upgrades, buff and perks... My hideout is basically an empty warehouse looking place with a few key elements so I can get my buffs...Low level instances – The balance on the low level 4 player instances can be frustrating.  They can be very difficult to beat at the level they claim to be designed for, and often a high level player will be in it, which seems to make it harder for everyone else.  It's not really free to play – This depends on your perspective, for me, I don't expect games to be totally free... either I need to buy it, or buy things in microtransactions, or pay for monthly. Nothing is free. I like FTP that lets me try a game like this before committing to it with a monthly sub.  The problem is, when I subbed, I had no idea what endgame was like, or that I'd basically be grinding for gear... **************** The Ugly things – Not too many ugly things here... *******************The Grind – Yes, I mentioned it before, but it really gets annoying past 30.  Even though more and more content opens up as you increase your level tier... All it really amounts to, is new instances to grind for marks.  There are no new levels, no new story arcs (not really).  If DCUO had proper content expansions for post 30, something to give you a REAL reason to level up (new story arcs, new levels etc), it would really be something special and give you a reason to grind. No cross platform between PC and PS4, but you CAN play PS4 with PS3. - This sucks for people like me who are master race PC users, but whose friends and family are all Console limited.  My Son and Wife both wanted to play with me, but can't... but at least they can play together... without me! :(********************* Final Verdict *********************Totally worth playing till 30, and a little beyond. Totally worth a short sub to unlock all the powers etc, or buy them outright one by one to save some money. I subbed for 3 months, and will cancel before it renews. I got my fun out of it, and will sub again only if any major additions or changes warrant it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												For the record, if this wasn't free to play, or if Champions Online was (for real, though, it's not really free), I wouldn't recommend it. Just saying.DC Universe Online is one of the best superhero MMOs. It's better than anything Marvel has done in the MMO field. It's at least on par with Champions Online (I don't like CO, but some do, and I've not played it much). I'd even say it's one of the better superhero games ever made. Even so, it's still only mediocre.Don't mistake me. The first few hours are fun, and just running/climbing/flying through the city is a lot of fun. The character customization options are limited, but passable. The abilty trees are interesting, but you're gonna want to pick a path you like pretty early on, or risk getting stuck at the difficulty curve right about level 16 and being stuck with your current abilities for a while until you finally get leveling again.That difficulty curve around levels 15-19 is obnoxious, and convinced me to stop plpaying. If I have put in more money than $10 for a DLC pack, I would have been more committed, but since it was largely a free experience, there was no investment to redeem. Again, the game being free made it worth it, and the ability to play the entire game, unrestricted, free of charge makes this far more worth your time and money than Champions Online in my book.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Here's a little background to justify my statements. I started playing this game shortly after release as a FREE player. DCUO at that point was fairly balanced and didn't show much of a P2W advantage for being a premium member and paying for the sub, but there were some advantages. Having a limited amount of usable credits on hand wasn't a big deal if you knew how to manage your spending and income you could side step the escrow emplaced on the F2P players. I later paid for the premium and maintained it for about 3 months, allowing me to make new characters with the new powers they released in the expansions (when I cancelled my sub, I lost access to the expansions, but was able to maintain the characters made from them) which was the main reason for me getting the premuim for that duration.This game is fun, the play style is exciting and is enhanced moreso when playing with a friend. The outfit choices are pleasing and the higher tier gear has those iconic looks that everyone should crave.This game has a low level cap mainly because it's designed for end game PVP, the PVP is unbalanced and broken, good luck finding anyone to go up against in the 8 vs 8 arena. They added a cool down to the que and made it cost real money to run more than once a day on pretty much all instances and arenas (which are the end game things to do). Basically after hitting 30 and having done all your main story line mission, you'll get bored real quick and decide to play something that has more to offer.I suggest finding a different game until the devs make some major changes to this game.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2012
												Marvel Comics "DC Universe" is a simulation title, which allows the player to pretend to be a little girl, pretending to be a super hero, or villian.  You will spend several hours selecting combination of tights and capes which are not as inhumanly offensive to the eye possible, and then mash the "1" through "4" keys repetedly untill completion.  The game ends when players collect all of the missing pages of the Necronomicon, and return the missing $20 to Slenderman.  There is a twist ending, where the players and Christopher Walken go to Denny's, but it's only achievable by using Canadian currency in the slenderman scenario.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												DC Universe is one of the best games I ever played. I got addicted to it real quick. It's easy to learn but hard to master. Progression is 1-30 then T1-T6. 1-30 takes you a day and I mean an ENTIRE day if you spend the WHOLE day grinding non-stop. If you're a working man who only has a couple of hours each day, it'll take you a week. With a party it's a lot faster. You have to join a league or else you'll get nowhere in this game. Please don't PUG too much. Plan instances with your league. You'll get♥♥♥♥♥♥done much faster that way. You have to get membership after level 30 because you won't be able to progress without it as you lack all the DLC's. And last thing, if you only have two hours a day to play this game, then this game is not for you. I'm saying that because you wouldn't be getting the full experience, only a sample. Yes, it's P2W but it's worth it. I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Oh man, I should know better than to review an MMO.  I've been playing on and off since Beta how many years ago.  The BIGGEST problem now is the community is very toxic.   The game just has that feeling of an MMO on its way out and the company is just rushing to squeeze whatever money they can before that happens.  The game itself feels like a lot of wasted potential, because it really should have been great.Free to Play. Your Way.  Should be grounds for a lawsuit, because in actuality, you'll have a hard time getting through the base content without putting in $5 to get bumped up to preferred status or whatever it's called these days.  $5 isn't bad deal but then you'll quickly realize that you can't get mid tier gear because of the cost restrictions so you'll have to either pay the sub, stay where you are, or pay to get an escrow unlock.  You're better off paying for the sub.This game is a grind, once you hit max level, 30, which can be done in a week without much effort if you're close to semi-hardcore.  Up to 3 weeks if you're pretty casual.  Once you hit level 30, grats because its all farming content for a tier gear upgrade.  Which isn't all bad, but its not varied enough, the contact packs are all pretty small and once you get past the lower level ones, there isn't much incentive to go back and do them so it becomes content that you paid for, but you've stopped using.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												For a free game, it's very entertaining, and certainly worth trying if you are okay with making a separate account. The customization is impressive, graphics detailed, and performance generally good. Many parts of this game make it unique, but still has the classic MMORPG theme to it, making players of that genre already familiar with the gameplay. My complaints are that, while the game is certainly not Pay-To-Win, every indent and corner seems to have a slot for accepting money. They have implemented almost every form of premium goodies I can think of. This includes crates, skins, furniture, items, and equipment. There's even a cap to the amount of money you can have on hand, and you need to pay real money to access the extra. I do agree that the developers have put an astonishing amount of work and detail into the game, and the company should receive payment for it's work, but the game almost begs for it. If you can ignore the features added solely for sinking money, then I would definitely recommend giving this a go.Oh, and the Bee-themed enemies are super annoying.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												It takes a certain alchemy for an MMO to grab me. I've tried several, and most I just get bored of. This one... is different. I love how easy it is to express a character concept. I love the combat, the questing, the fact that I get to interact with recognizable characters. I love how invested I get in the characters I create.As I mentioned, it takes a lot for me to really play an MMO seriously; at the time of this review, I've logged 50.5 hours in two weeks. It takes even more to get me to engage in microtransactions in an MMO. At the time of this review, I've spent probably about $50 in this game, including the monthly subscription, which is a thing I've never done before.So yeah. I like this game. I like it a lot.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												For a free game, it's very entertaining, and certainly worth trying if you are okay with making a separate account. The customization is impressive, graphics detailed, and performance generally good. Many parts of this game make it unique, but still has the classic MMORPG theme to it, making players of that genre already familiar with the gameplay. My complaints are that, while the game is certainly not Pay-To-Win, every indent and corner seems to have a slot for accepting money. They have implemented almost every form of premium goodies I can think of. This includes crates, skins, furniture, items, and equipment. There's even a cap to the amount of money you can have on hand, and you need to pay real money to access the extra. I do agree that the developers have put an astonishing amount of work and detail into the game, and the company should receive payment for it's work, but the game almost begs for it. If you can ignore the features added solely for sinking money, then I would definitely recommend giving this a go.Oh, and the Bee-themed enemies are super annoying.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												It takes a certain alchemy for an MMO to grab me. I've tried several, and most I just get bored of. This one... is different. I love how easy it is to express a character concept. I love the combat, the questing, the fact that I get to interact with recognizable characters. I love how invested I get in the characters I create.As I mentioned, it takes a lot for me to really play an MMO seriously; at the time of this review, I've logged 50.5 hours in two weeks. It takes even more to get me to engage in microtransactions in an MMO. At the time of this review, I've spent probably about $50 in this game, including the monthly subscription, which is a thing I've never done before.So yeah. I like this game. I like it a lot.

												Was a good game, the PVP was great. Servers got hacked but everybody was compensated with Batman style masks etc..  Then for European players like myself, i was moved to ProSeiben (spell) servers. Took 2 weeks to get my characters back. My Batman mask was gone and "there was nothing they could do"  about that. I had to change my log in name to start playing again.All set up again after the server move, i start playing again, i create 16 new characters, i am still a little sore about not getting my batman mask after my personal details were hacked but i continued on. THen i get an email that i am being moved server again. After a 2 hour rigmarole i managed to change server. But not until i change my Username again !!  I change server and everything seems a little quiet. 6 months later i am yet to see a bad guy on the server. So i can no longer play. Time and money invested in this game wasted. Just feel messed about by them at this stage.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This game is fun for about 15 minutes. Based heavily on the gameplay and engine from the Justice League games on console this game offers prettier graphics but very little depth. There really isn't a consistent story to pull a player in. You can choose a mentor which sets you up with a loose storyline to follow but is bisected, quadrasected, basically chopped to bits by other intersecting mini stories. And that's a large part of the problem. There isn't any reason to KEEP playing the game besides leveling up and getting better items. But to what end? To play the same mini stories and complete the same redundant tasks. Don't get me wrong I am not saying the game is all bad. What I am saying is that if DCU was a food it would taste like carboard. Considering the age of the game and the lack of changes and updates made over the YEARS it has existed it's pretty obvious there aren't many plans for improving the game at all. The powers you get to choose from are quite limited and become pretty bland when so many other players have the exact same powers you do. The ability to create a unique hero or villain is extremely limited. I would recommend this game as again a least of the terrible games Steam offers. Be prepared to hit a ceiling unless you want to pay for membership though because this is definitely a money game. And if I am going to spend money on a game it damn sure won't be this one. Play it for free, have a little fun, and get rid of it.

content:
Posted: March 23
												I've played several superhero mmorpgs and this is the best.  That doesn't mean its all good.Pros:-Great costume choices and customization-Great link ins to the great DC franchise (God knows we aren't getting it in the current DC movies) !!!!!!!!-Still high population-F2P-Good CommunityCons:-End game is terrible: you will repeat the same instances over and over and over and over....oh and they are time locked or pay (and this is true even if you are a subscriber...wtf)-Subscribing is near uselss don't waste your money-All powers while they look different really aren't...and you will hit the same combos over and over and over-There is like 2 builds for a power that are acceptable in the endgame...if you don't do them you are useless-End game makes you feel useless and weak anyhowI've thought about booting this up a couple times lately...started the updater then about 5 minutes in realize how much the end really turned me away from the game.  Each time I stop the updater and I don't regret it.  I am of the mind that if its something in the beginning that bugs you about an mmorpg, grind through it for the good stuff, but if its at the end then whats the point of playing on?  I did love this game and had a blast playing it with some great people but I can't see myself booting it up again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												When you start it, it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The customization is great, the free roam is really amazing, with fun huge maps. Not only that but the super powers make the free roam MUCH better (flying, parkour/climb, and super speed). This game is great! I played it for a long time, but the problem with it is that it sucks when you get high level, it just becomes mostly grind "x" amount of enemies at this location, and then you get less boss fights (which are fun af). This review is written from memory and I don't know if they changed anything. I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU START THOUGH, just to get hooked. Note there is DLC and an ingmae currency for some powers and wicked armour but see that's not that important unless you wanna be OP. I was never so invested that I'd visit forums or see what devs are doing (I was younger so I wasn't following updates). tl;dr just play it and see if you like the late game experience. Starts great though!

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Quick to log in and play, combat is fast, fun, hard hitting and intense at times! Resembles 3rd person games where the combat is consequential. Still has a health system, although quickly paced. Traveling is perfect if you choose your favourite method. Grappling reminds me of the 90's batman cartoons, as does the acrobatics to move around, flight reminds me of the cinematics in Injustice: Gods Among us and is just awesome! Super speed reminds me of The Flash trailer and looks extremely reminiscient of that. More than worth the download if you are a superhero fan.

Its still a fun free to play game, but if you play this and a few other of their mmo I would pay for the year member ship. Well worth the money for a year of fun it multiple games.Its free so install it and take it for a spin, you got nothing to lose.

content:
Posted: March 23
												I've played several superhero mmorpgs and this is the best.  That doesn't mean its all good.Pros:-Great costume choices and customization-Great link ins to the great DC franchise (God knows we aren't getting it in the current DC movies) !!!!!!!!-Still high population-F2P-Good CommunityCons:-End game is terrible: you will repeat the same instances over and over and over and over....oh and they are time locked or pay (and this is true even if you are a subscriber...wtf)-Subscribing is near uselss don't waste your money-All powers while they look different really aren't...and you will hit the same combos over and over and over-There is like 2 builds for a power that are acceptable in the endgame...if you don't do them you are useless-End game makes you feel useless and weak anyhowI've thought about booting this up a couple times lately...started the updater then about 5 minutes in realize how much the end really turned me away from the game.  Each time I stop the updater and I don't regret it.  I am of the mind that if its something in the beginning that bugs you about an mmorpg, grind through it for the good stuff, but if its at the end then whats the point of playing on?  I did love this game and had a blast playing it with some great people but I can't see myself booting it up again.

content:
Posted: March 23
												When you start it, it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The customization is great, the free roam is really amazing, with fun huge maps. Not only that but the super powers make the free roam MUCH better (flying, parkour/climb, and super speed). This game is great! I played it for a long time, but the problem with it is that it sucks when you get high level, it just becomes mostly grind "x" amount of enemies at this location, and then you get less boss fights (which are fun af). This review is written from memory and I don't know if they changed anything. I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU START THOUGH, just to get hooked. Note there is DLC and an ingmae currency for some powers and wicked armour but see that's not that important unless you wanna be OP. I was never so invested that I'd visit forums or see what devs are doing (I was younger so I wasn't following updates). tl;dr just play it and see if you like the late game experience. Starts great though!

												When I first played this game (quite some time ago) it was kinda meh. Didn't really have any reason to keep playing, story was meh, my character felt meh, just MEH.YEARS later. If you are into MMO's it's fine, and the system of subscription is SUPER fair (especially if you play other daybreak games), but honestly, I got tired of this game even faster than I did the first time around. TL;DRIf you like action MMO's and have a good connection speed, give it a shot, you might love it. For this old man, however, it really doesn't offer anything special at all, and is underwhelming in general.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This game is fun for about 15 minutes. Based heavily on the gameplay and engine from the Justice League games on console this game offers prettier graphics but very little depth. There really isn't a consistent story to pull a player in. You can choose a mentor which sets you up with a loose storyline to follow but is bisected, quadrasected, basically chopped to bits by other intersecting mini stories. And that's a large part of the problem. There isn't any reason to KEEP playing the game besides leveling up and getting better items. But to what end? To play the same mini stories and complete the same redundant tasks. Don't get me wrong I am not saying the game is all bad. What I am saying is that if DCU was a food it would taste like carboard. Considering the age of the game and the lack of changes and updates made over the YEARS it has existed it's pretty obvious there aren't many plans for improving the game at all. The powers you get to choose from are quite limited and become pretty bland when so many other players have the exact same powers you do. The ability to create a unique hero or villain is extremely limited. I would recommend this game as again a least of the terrible games Steam offers. Be prepared to hit a ceiling unless you want to pay for membership though because this is definitely a money game. And if I am going to spend money on a game it damn sure won't be this one. Play it for free, have a little fun, and get rid of it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												EDIT: According to another player you can restore your old characters for free, so ignore that.I'm trying to figure out what made me redownload this game, but for the life of me I cannot comprehend what was going through my head.I'll try to be fair and start off this review with things I like about the game.1.Voice acting.The game is almost fully voice acted, and it is done rather well.Some classic voice actors are in this cast, such as mark hamill as the joker, The cutscenes are really nice too, animatic comic shorts with fun dialog.2.CombatThe combat, whilst simplistic at it's core with a rock papper scissors theme with blocking ranged and melee, is rather fun.There are many abilities many weapons and a good ammount of combo's making this feel like a nice action beat uhm up.3.Visually appealing sceneryThe graphics look nice, not 100% modern anymore, but still polished with a few different areas with unique feels between gotham and metropolis.4.Let's you be a hero OR villian.A lot of games now a days have this "nothing is black and white" mentality when it comes to factions.There are usually multiple factions and no one is set in a better light than the other.But in this game you can be outright evil if you want to. (though sadly there is no middle ground or multiple choices, you're either a criminal or a hero)Now onto the reasons why this game is a failure, has failed, and will hopefully shut down.1.Free to play, expensive to enjoy.This game will attempt to squeeze every penny out of you if you let it.Not only are almost half of the power types behind a paywall, there are even basic in game features most mmo games don't even consider making you pay real life money for caged off behind pay walls.One of the worst offenders of this is money in game.That's right, the money you pick up off the ground in game has a limit.1,500$ of in game currency is all you can pick up.If you pick up any more of that without spending it...well, that money is gone now.You can't use it, you can't get to it, but you can look at it taunting you all day just begging you to spend real life cash to get to it.Not a problem you think to yourself, I'll just pay the price of unlocking infinite money an- NO! WRONG!It is a monthly cost to increase your money limit.And it comes in levels.First level?2.5k currency Second,Infinite.So there are two layers of paywalls just to get infinite cash, to use the money you earned to buy things.It's either that or buy tokens to unlock some of the money just once.There are also entire episodes (raids/areas) hidden behind 5 dollar pay walls as well.Just scroll up from this and go look at how much it costs to unlock all of the DLC of this game.Now add up that along with a 15 dollar per month charge just to 'fully' enjoy the game.Fun right?2.Monthly charge option in a F2P game.This is probably the dumbest thing any of these games can do.There is a reason your game couldn't keep using a monthly fee model and survive.It's an outdated archiac payment model.I would almost gladly pay 30 bucks for this game if they removed the money cap and monthly pay option, and just made the things you can buy vanity items.That's how almost 100% of the successful F2P games do it.This game is doomed to shut down just from that, at least till some of the die hard fans start losing their nerve as well.3. Limited to two character slots in F2P.I don't know about you, but a game all about making a unique character should allow you to toy around with more than 2 options.I usually use my second slot for test characters, but everytime I made it to level 10 on one of them, I ended up deleting them because I knew it would be permanent and I couldn't try out any other combinations.So be absolutely sure what you have it what you want, because if you have two characters you don't like, one has to be deleted to make another.4.Huge gear gap.This game has a severe gear gap between new and old school players, and the only way to really fix the gap is to buy some of the newer raids to keep up with the new gear sets.Even tokens in game for buying gear have a currency cap as well, so you will constantly need to go back and forth buying single pieces of gear, going back out and grinding more money, just constantly refreshing your money.I took to buying expensive vendor items and reselling them as currency, which is an painful way to work around the issue of the money cap.I spent a long time trying to grind pvp and money to finally buy a full set of epics in the game.I thought I was pretty well geared, everything I had was a massive upgrade from the blues I had.But along came a plasma glowing shield wielding man, covered head to toe in cash shop effects and a money blocked weapon set.I spent 15 minutes blocking all of his heavy attacks, smashing his ranged attacks, and breaking through his blocks.After all that time I still did no damage to him, and frustrated that he couldn't kill me, he finally just slowly flew away anticlimactically after giving up.There are no words for how depressing that is, to totally outclass someone, but be unable to even hurt them, so eventually they just leave after getting bored.5.RETURNING PLAYERS ARE PUNISHED WITH DELETED CHARACTERS TRAPPED BEHIND A PAYWALL.This is the thing that stung the most for me, when I redownloaded this game and booted it up, I was told to make a new character.That's fine, I don't expect them to keep the data of a guy who hasn't played in who knows how long.Slight problem though....THEY DID HAVE MY DATA, but they wanted me to pay FIFTEEN DOLLARS to recover it.Wow, the most underhanded slimey thing I can think of for a F2P title to do, hold your characters hostage.To massive fans of this game who don't want it to change and who are happy to see it stay exactly how it is, know this.This is a video game, and a business, it will shut down if it keeps this up.The console release of this game could be make or break, so please, let some of the criticism come through.Mark my words, if this game doesn't change it's ways soon, it will go down in under a year.Unless the small number of you who pay to play seriously can keep it afloat, in which case bravo, you're successfully made a game into a buy in club for just you and a select group.These types of games, even this one, tend to only survive based on their non paying, or frequent but not monthly pay players.They keep the community diverse and add to the population, giving you monthly paying customers more people to group and play with, and if the market place wasn't so unaccessible due to the money cap, more people to buy your items in game or sell you something you need.I've slammed down anywhere between 50 and 200 bucks on other games with F2P models, and I don't regret it at all.But this game is making me regret playing it for free.That's a serious problem when you can't even keep cheapskates interested in a "free" product.Bottom line, don't waste your time with this game.The download is rather large if you don't have great internet, and while leveling can be a fun experience once you max out and start thinking about getting sets, working on your character, decorating your hideout, you'll find more roadblocks and annoyances than you would care to stomach.It becomes a pain just trying to manage what little funds you have with what you want, and the game just becomes really unrewarding and punishes you for trying harder with it's money caps and huge gear gaps for late comers.The game pretty much punishes you for getting invested in it, or punishes your wallet if you cave in.There are bad greedy business practices afoot here, and a gaggle of fanboys ready to defend those practices as well.You don't need these problems.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Awesome game. I usually don't play many mmo's but this one was addictive. Awesome graphics and handling. Controls are incredibly fluid, more fluid then a lot of action games. One nice feature, that I've never seen in an MMORPG, is the focus on making a world feel large and immersive by making the world large vertically. You can climb up large skyscrapers and jump down from them or fly around the cities. After the level cap at 30, it can get repetitive, so you'll want to find a league to keep you company. You can also just create another character with a different role, ability, and/or mentor and play through the main game again. It has a decent amount of customization options and collectibles to find. There's a lot to do in this game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												EDIT: According to another player you can restore your old characters for free, so ignore that.I'm trying to figure out what made me redownload this game, but for the life of me I cannot comprehend what was going through my head.I'll try to be fair and start off this review with things I like about the game.1.Voice acting.The game is almost fully voice acted, and it is done rather well.Some classic voice actors are in this cast, such as mark hamill as the joker, The cutscenes are really nice too, animatic comic shorts with fun dialog.2.CombatThe combat, whilst simplistic at it's core with a rock papper scissors theme with blocking ranged and melee, is rather fun.There are many abilities many weapons and a good ammount of combo's making this feel like a nice action beat uhm up.3.Visually appealing sceneryThe graphics look nice, not 100% modern anymore, but still polished with a few different areas with unique feels between gotham and metropolis.4.Let's you be a hero OR villian.A lot of games now a days have this "nothing is black and white" mentality when it comes to factions.There are usually multiple factions and no one is set in a better light than the other.But in this game you can be outright evil if you want to. (though sadly there is no middle ground or multiple choices, you're either a criminal or a hero)Now onto the reasons why this game is a failure, has failed, and will hopefully shut down.1.Free to play, expensive to enjoy.This game will attempt to squeeze every penny out of you if you let it.Not only are almost half of the power types behind a paywall, there are even basic in game features most mmo games don't even consider making you pay real life money for caged off behind pay walls.One of the worst offenders of this is money in game.That's right, the money you pick up off the ground in game has a limit.1,500$ of in game currency is all you can pick up.If you pick up any more of that without spending it...well, that money is gone now.You can't use it, you can't get to it, but you can look at it taunting you all day just begging you to spend real life cash to get to it.Not a problem you think to yourself, I'll just pay the price of unlocking infinite money an- NO! WRONG!It is a monthly cost to increase your money limit.And it comes in levels.First level?2.5k currency Second,Infinite.So there are two layers of paywalls just to get infinite cash, to use the money you earned to buy things.It's either that or buy tokens to unlock some of the money just once.There are also entire episodes (raids/areas) hidden behind 5 dollar pay walls as well.Just scroll up from this and go look at how much it costs to unlock all of the DLC of this game.Now add up that along with a 15 dollar per month charge just to 'fully' enjoy the game.Fun right?2.Monthly charge option in a F2P game.This is probably the dumbest thing any of these games can do.There is a reason your game couldn't keep using a monthly fee model and survive.It's an outdated archiac payment model.I would almost gladly pay 30 bucks for this game if they removed the money cap and monthly pay option, and just made the things you can buy vanity items.That's how almost 100% of the successful F2P games do it.This game is doomed to shut down just from that, at least till some of the die hard fans start losing their nerve as well.3. Limited to two character slots in F2P.I don't know about you, but a game all about making a unique character should allow you to toy around with more than 2 options.I usually use my second slot for test characters, but everytime I made it to level 10 on one of them, I ended up deleting them because I knew it would be permanent and I couldn't try out any other combinations.So be absolutely sure what you have it what you want, because if you have two characters you don't like, one has to be deleted to make another.4.Huge gear gap.This game has a severe gear gap between new and old school set.I spent 15 minutes blocking all of his heavy attacks, smashing his ranged attacks, and breaking through his blocks.After all that time I still did no damage to him, and frustrated that he couldn't they just leave after getting bored.5.RETURNING PLAYERS ARE PUNISHED WITH DELETED CHARACTERS TRAPPED BEHIND A PAYWALL.This is the thing that stung the most for me, when I redownloaded this game and
